subject: Fix eqlx endless loop when server closes the connection
commit_message:
Fix eqlx endless loop when server closes the connection

The eqlx driver would identify one CLI command completion by looking
for the system name prompt in the output ("ARRAY_NAME>"). But some
cases where there is no "ARRAY_NAME>" in the output. The eqlx server
closes the ssh connection immediately after sends such message, which
lead to a infinite loop in _get_output() and 100% CPU utilization.

What the patch does is to check the return of chan.recv(), if the
length of returned string is zero, which means server has closed the
connection, the loop will be exited.

Closes-Bug: #1410627

subject: Fix networks not cleaned up on reschedule
commit_message:
Fix networks not cleaned up on reschedule

Until now, when an instance is rescheduled due to a failed
spawn the existing network structure that has been set up
can be used from a subsequent host because it it not host
specific. The only exception to this was when using the
Ironic. Now DVR has been introduced in neutron, network
ports are bound to a specific host. As a result any created
ports will be bound to the wrong host when an instance is
rescheduled and the new instance will not be connected to
its networks.

One solution is to add code that updates the port binding
in the spawn of a rescheduled instance, but that is as
complex as creating them in the first place.

As an alternative, this patch adds a method to the network
api called deallocate_on_reschedule(). This returns False
by default but is over ridden in the neutron api to return
True if the port binding extension is in use. This is used
to trigger network cleanup on reschule as is currently done
for the virt driver to cater for Ironic.

This alternative avoids unecessary complexity and keeps the
existing behavior for other network implementations.

Closes-Bug: #1410739
Change-Id: I7c59a7cadf1d9b65b975a714d89e7636fc3ca7b1

subject: Fix connecting unnecessary iSCSI sessions issue
commit_message:
Fix connecting unnecessary iSCSI sessions issue

In Icehouse with "iscsi_use_multipath=true", attaching a multipath
iSCSI volume may create unnecessary iSCSI sessions.

The iscsiadm discovery command in connect_volume() returns all of the
targets in the Cinder node, not just the ones related to the multipath
volume which is specified by iqn. If the storage has many targets,
connecting to all these volumes will also result in many unnecessary
connections.

There are two types of iSCSI multipath devices. One which shares
the same iqn between multiple portals, and the other which use
different iqns on different portals. connect_volume() needs to
identify the type by checking iscsiadm the output if the iqn is
used by multiple portals.

This patch changes the behavior of attaching volume:

   1. Identify the type by checking the iscsiadm output.
   2. Connect to the correct targets by connect_to_iscsi_portal().

Closes-Bug: #1382440

(cherry picked from commit fb0de106f2f15604750bafc318ba06c41070cc35)

subject: Fix eqlx endless loop when server closes the connection

The eqlx driver would identify one CLI command completion by looking
for the system name prompt in the output ("ARRAY_NAME>"). But some
cases where there is no "ARRAY_NAME>" in the output. The eqlx server
closes the ssh connection immediately after sends such message, which
lead to a infinite loop in _get_output() and 100% CPU utilization.

length of returned string is zero, which means server has closed the
connection, the loop will be exited.

subject: Implement clone_image caching on SolidFire
commit_message:
Implement clone_image caching on SolidFire

When performing boot from Volume on none FS based devices or devices
that aren't also acting as Glance Image stores, the current process goes
like this:
1. Fetch the image from Glance Store to a temp file on the Cinder Node
2. Perform a qemu-img convert on that file (convert to raw)
3. Transfer the contents of that file to the newly created Volume using dd

This process can take a while and is pretty inefficient. This BP introduces
the option for Operators to enable image-caching on the SolidFire backend device.

When enabled this option will use the existing Cinder clone_image method,
and will create a "Template Volume" of minimum required size on the SolidFire
backend. This Volume will be created with a backend SolidFire account that can
be shared among OpenStack Tenants.

When a request is received we first do a number of checks before proceeding:
1. Is Image/Template caching enabled
2. Inspect the image-metadata and verify that the image is public,
   or that the tenant making the request is the owner
3. Verify that the image-metadata includes the properties['virtual_size']
   parameter

If the preconditions are met, create a minimal sized Volume with the requested
image; then use SolidFires clone operation to create the requested bootable
Volume. During the process we also check and make sure that the image hasn't
been updated since we created our cached copy, if it has we then delete the
copy we have on the system and create a new one.

Also updated those drivers with docstrings duplicating the params info.  I did
not rewrite or modify those that didn't include changed info.  I'm not sure we
should duplicate docstring info for base methods like this anyway, but that's
irrelevant for this work.

Change-Id: I2fac9410f504dff1aaa9fe0b9a274db7b074fa50
Implements: blueprint implement-solidfire-cloneimage

subject: Make service-delete work in API cells
commit_message:
Make service-delete work in API cells

nova service-delete is handled by HostAPI.service_delete method.
Normally, it searches for relevant Service object in DB and calls
destroy() on it. However, in API cell it is over-ridden so that
service_delete message can be routed to appropriate cell. Once the
destination cell is reached, the message processor invokes
HostAPI.service_delete to perform the actual delete. This works in
case of child cells.
However in case of API cells, since HostAPI.service_delete has been
over-ridden, when the message processor invokes HostAPI.service_delete
to perform actual delete of the service, the API cell tries to again
route the message and fails in doing so with an AttributeError (as
the message is already at the destination cell and can not be further
routed).
This patch moves the object destroy() call to a separate function and
modifies the message processor to call the new function. The original
service_delete is modified to also call the new function.

If the image is deleted by appropriate API call while its content

subject: Specify prefix length for IPv6 subnets
commit_message:
Specify prefix length for IPv6 subnets

If Network contains dhcpv6-stateful Subnet with prefix other than /64,
dnsmasq refuses to start if prefix-len is not specified in dhcp-range
option.  From dnsmasq(8) manpage:

    For IPv6, the parameters are slightly different: instead of netmask
    and broadcast address, there is an optional prefix length which must
    be equal to or larger then the prefix length on the local interface.
    If not given, this defaults to 64. Unlike the IPv4 case, the prefix
    length is not automatically derived from the interface
    configuration. The mimimum size of the prefix length is 64.

It is safe to always specify prefix length, so dnsmasq will use correct
configuration.

subject: Use tgt-admin --update ALL
commit_message:
Use tgt-admin --update ALL

For target creation using tgtadm driver, we create a persistence
file for the target, then send a tgt-admin --update 'name' where
name is the specific persistence file we want to read in and update
from.

It turns out that we can hit race conditions where the persistence
file is written, and an update is requested but target has already
done work to make it believe that the target has already been created.

There are two ways this might be fixed:
1. Just catch the already exists exception, wait a second and retry
2. Try and use an update ALL instead of a targeted file

The update ALL option doesn't care what currently exists or is active,
it just reads everything in the persistence file and verifies there's a
target for each entry.  It should not reset or impact in-use targets
because we're not using the --force option.

(and how that affects node.target_provision_state). The fsm's _target_state
doesn't always get updated, when it "should".

I went through all the patches in this series as well as all the states
and state transitions in the code, adding or fixing unit tests so that we have
complete (or more complete) coverage of all the code paths which include an
fsm.process_event().

Since there seem to be issues with getting the node's .target_provision_state
right (ie, with the values prior to the fsm change), wherever a unit test
specified a node's provision_state, I also added its corresponding
target_provision_state. Just in case. (So far, it seems like given a
provision_state, there is only one possible target_provision_state).

I didn't check if there are unit tests that provide full coverage of
task_manager.process_event(). (Although indirectly, I think the other unit
tests cover task_manager.process_event().)

With respect to the FSM, I was unable to find code paths that exercised the
following (from ironic.common.states.py):

  machine.add_state(DEPLOYDONE, target=ACTIVE, **watchers)
  machine.add_state(DELETED, target=NOSTATE, **watchers)
  machine.add_transition(NOSTATE, ERROR, 'error')
  machine.add_transition(DEPLOYING, ERROR, 'error')
  machine.add_transition(ACTIVE, ERROR, 'error')

Some unit tests will fail due to this. That is expected until we figure
out how to address them.

Some thoughts:
1. we may be able to get away without the fsm._target_state variable/logic.
I was wondering if we could use a state's 'target' information to determine
the desired ._target_state for the current state.

2. I was also thinking that if we could do 1, we might be able to get
away from even having/setting a node.target_provision_state, if that value
can be determined via the node's provision_state and the fsm.

3. I am wondering if we need to change the fsm to clearly indicate which
states are active vs momentary vs fail vs passive. We have explicit user
requests to go to certain states, but how do we eg transition from a
momentary (-ED) state to a passive state?

(I may have scattered other thoughts as comments through these changes.)

subject: pip download-cache is deprecated
commit_message:
pip download-cache is deprecated

The pip-download cache is deprecated and not functional since pip 6.0,
it should be removed.

Instead of the PIP_DOWNLOAD_CACHE variable this change
adds the PIP_EXTRA_ARGS variable, which makes possible to
use arbitrary pip argument including the --find-links,
which can be used for using pre downloaded
archives for installation:
https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/user_guide.html#fast-local-installs

NOTES:
PIP_EXTRA_ARGS is not good for passing arguments including white spaces.
However most option can be configured in the pip.conf as well.

'PIP_FIND_LINKS' environment variable exists, where we could specify
multiple links separated by space, but the --find-links argument can be used
multiple times so handling spaces is not so important.
PIP_EXTRA_ARGS can be used for other arguments and can be
good enough for covering other than find-links use cases.
